headline.main: Sleep Anxiety Leads Many to the Medicine Cabinet

docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S hard to write this sentence: There is something women don't do as well as men. Sleep.
docs.snippet: There is something women don't do as well as men: sleep. And many respond by taking a pill.

headline.main: Serialize Me: America, 30 Days at a Time

docs.lead_paragraph: IF it had been up to Morgan Spurlock -- and his fiancée, Alex Jamieson, makes it immediately clear that it was not -- the director-guinea pig of the film ''Super Size Me'' would have been not just the creator, producer and host of his new ''30 Days'' documentary series on the FX cable network, he'd have been the subject of all six episodes, including the one involving 30 days of binge drinking and another focused on 30 days of taking steroids and human growth hormone. ''The original idea was that each episode I'd go through something that would examine an issue in America,'' said Mr. Spurlock, whose 2004 film chronicling his 30-day McDonald's-only eating experiment earned him an Academy Award nomination and a host of international film festival prizes and went on to become the third-highest-grossing documentary of all time (behind only Michael Moore's ''Fahrenheit 911'' and ''Bowling for Columbine''). It also jacked up his blood pressure and cholesterol, damaged his liver, put 25 extra pounds around his midsection and wreaked havoc on his relationship with Ms. Jamieson, a vegan chef, who is seen in ''Super Size Me'' lamenting the Big Mac-induced effects on his health, his libido and his state of mind.
docs.snippet: Sick of McDonald's, Morgan Spurlock heads to cable to satisfy new appetites.

headline.main: Paying Attention to That Pain in the Chest: It Could Be Serious

docs.lead_paragraph: WOMEN and men share one characteristic when it comes to heart disease: it's the leading killer of both. But otherwise, much is different -- and not always to women's benefit. For instance, women don't usually experience the classic chest-clutching symptoms. Their first warning sign may be pain in the jaw or neck, fatigue, shortness of breath, a stomachache or nausea, all of which could be associated with another condition. Even the classic chest pain can be misinterpreted. ''A lot of women come to me saying their bras feel too tight,'' said Dr. Maryann McLaughlin, assistant professor of cardiology at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine in Manhattan.
docs.snippet: Areas where women can address their vulnerabilities to heart attacks.

headline.kicker: AT LUNCH WITH -- JEFFREY P. ANSELL
headline.main: The Truth About Cats, Dogs and Executives

docs.lead_paragraph: JEFFREY P. ANSELL is definitely a corporate guy. Otherwise, why wear a tie to Fred's, a casual restaurant on the Upper West Side of Manhattan that is rife with pictures of dogs? Why bring sales charts and such to lunch -- and have public relations people follow through with offers of more? And why sprinkle product plugs throughout a conversation, despite a reporter's pledge to keep those plugs from appearing in print?
docs.snippet: Jeffrey P. Ansell is the president of the Iams Company, the arm of Procter & Gamble that sells food for cats and dogs.

docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has sent a team of specialists into a state, West Virginia, to study an outbreak of obesity in the same way it studies an outbreak of an infectious disease. Kerri Kennedy, the program manager at the West Virginia Physical Activity and Nutrition Program, said the state had requested the agency's investigation.
docs.snippet: For the first time, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is studying an outbreak of obesity in the same way it studies an outbreak of an infectious disease.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Killing of Journalist Rocks Lebanon's Stability An outspoken journalist and opposition figure who railed against Syria's presence in Lebanon was killed by a car bomb, prompting accusations of continued Syrian meddling in the country's affairs and opposition calls for the ouster of the pro-Syrian president, Émile Lahoud. A1 AIDS Orphans Turn to Sex The AIDS epidemic in Sub-Saharan Africa has left orphaned and impoverished young girls who are being propelled into sex at shockingly early ages to support themselves, their siblings and, all too often, their own children. A1 Although a small but growing number of countries are beginning to contain the spread of the AIDS virus, the epidemic is expanding in all areas of the world, the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, said at a special session of the General Assembly to address the disease. A10 Video Gives Proof of Massacre A video of the execution of six Muslim men shown at the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia in The Hague is being seen as irrefutable evidence that Serbia's police forces, and not just Bosnian Serb forces, took part in the July 1995 massacre in Srebrenica. A3 Syria Tests Scud Missiles In the first such tests since 2001, Syria fired three Scud missiles, including one that broke up over Turkish territory and showered missile parts down onto unsuspecting Turkish farmers. A12 Attacks Kill 33 Across Iraq Insurgent attacks across a broad swath of central and northern Iraq killed at least 33 people and were the latest in a series of assaults that appear to be the response to an ambitious counterinsurgency effort led by the Iraqi government. A12 Two American soldiers who said high-ranking officers authorized them to use dogs to intimidate Iraqi detainees at Abu Ghraib prison have been charged with abuse. A12 Palestinian Prisoners Let Go Israel released 398 Palestinian prisoners at checkpoints in the West Bank and Gaza, from where they were transported to joyful reunions with family and friends. A6 French Cabinet Revamped President Jacques Chirac of France reshuffled his cabinet, firing his foreign minister and welcoming a political foe back into the cabinet as interior minister, in a struggle to win back the confidence of his people after the bruising defeat by French voters of a constitution for Europe. A8 North Korea Will Not Cooperate North Korea issued a series of verbal attacks that ruled out cooperation on retrieving American war dead from its territory, and called the American dispatch of F-117A Nighthawk stealth fighter jets to South Korea ''tantamount to turning a gun'' on Korean unity. A4 NATIONAL A14-21 Final Arguments Offer 2 Portraits of Jackson In their final arguments, lawyers for both sides in the child molesting trial of Michael Jackson painted widely divergent portraits of a singer whose fame once rivaled that of Elvis and the Beatles. A1 Bride-to-Be Pleads No Contest As part of a plea agreement, Jennifer Wilbanks, who faked her abduction days before her wedding, received two years' probation and was ordered to repay search costs. A14 Some Landslide Victims Return A day after a landslide destroyed or damaged almost 50 houses in Laguna Beach, Calf., and forced 1,000 residents to flee, hundreds began to return to their undamaged homes. A14 Arson Cited in Cleveland Fire Widespread grief over a house fire that killed a woman and eight children turned to anger with word that the blaze, at first thought to be accidental, was arson. A19 Bush Regroups on Social Plan President Bush vowed to spend time talking about Social Security every week until something was done, despite experiencing headwinds since the White House began a 60-cities-in-60-days tour for support. A20 Testimony Ends in Tobacco Trial After eight months, testimony in the conspiracy trial against the nation's leading tobacco companies ended with the defense's final witness. A20 SCIENCE/HEALTH Fly's Sexuality Shifts With Gene Researchers announced in the journal Cell that in a series of experiments they found that a female fruit fly, artificially endowed with a single male-type gene acted exactly like males in courtship. Males that were artificially given the female version of the gene turned their sexual attention to other males. A1 State Is Case Study in Obesity For the first time, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has sent specialists into a state, West Virginia, to study an outbreak of obesity. A14 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Parents on the Front Lines Of Resistance to Recruiters Parents have become one of the military's stiffest opponents two years into the war in Iraq. As the Army and Marines struggle to meet their goals for new recruits, parents are discouraging their children from serving in a war that many see as endless and unnecessary. A1 Ruling Favors Stadium Deal Supporters of a proposed Jets stadium on the West Side of Manhattan won an important court ruling that they hoped would persuade Albany lawmakers to approve it. But maneuvering on both sides of the issue was feverish. A1 Air Controllers Under Fire The Federal Aviation Administration said that abuses by some air traffic controllers at the office that handles traffic for the New York area's three major airports, as well as its own poor management, was costing it about $4 million a year in unnecessary overtime. B1 Wife Arrested in Slaying The wife of a New Jersey man whose body was hacked up, put in three suitcases and dumped off the Virginia coast more than a year ago was arrested in his slaying. B1 WEEKEND E1-30;E31-40 ESCAPES D1-12 SPORTSFRIDAY D1-7 Giambi Dropped by Nike Jason Giambi's status as a power hitter sought by companies to endorse their products took a hit when Nike announced it was ending its relationship with the troubled Yankee. D1 OBITUARIES B7 George Mikan The Minneapolis Lakers' center who was the first superstar in modern professional basketball and a player so big and so dominant that college and pro rules were changed in an effort to handcuff him, he was 80. B7 BUSINESS DAY C1-14 S.E.C. Chairman Nominated President Bush nominated Representative Christopher Cox, a conservative Republican from California, to replace William H. Donaldson as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. A1 A Challenge for New AOL As a struggling America Online introduces a free Internet portal, its position within Time Warner is in question, with speculation increasing that it could be sold. C1 Sun Makes $4.1 Billion Deal Sun Microsystems said it would acquire the Storage Technology Corporation, a maker of tape storage systems and disk drives, for $4.1 billion in cash, to broaden Sun's reach into the high end of the corporate computing market. C1 Changes at '60 Minutes' CBS's news division is struggling to find new places for employees who worked on the canceled Wednesday edition of ''60 Minutes,'' and must make room for Dan Rather amid the lineup of news correspondents on the Sunday edition of the program. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: Saying ''no'' to the stadium; the price of gold; an unlikely activist; a wary Congress gets off the tee. Column: Thomas L. Friedman. Crossword E28 TV Listings E29 Weather D8

headline.main: Fewer Friends In High Places For This Lobby

byline.original: By ALEXEI BARRIONUEVO and ELIZABETH BECKER; Alexei Barrionuevo reported from Chicago for this article and Elizabeth Becker from Washington

docs.abstract: Sugar industry is being blamed for hurting chance for passage of Bush administration's top trade priority, Central America Free Trade Agreement, known as Cafta; big agribusiness is siding with administration against sugar in one of rare instances of food lobby turning against one of its own; sugar industry appears poised to chalk up another victory for defeating Cafta; Democrats, who are united in opposition to Cafta, say Bush administration is using sugar as scapegoat; Congressional Hispanic caucus announced its opposition to Cafta last week, citing fear of job losses as chief reason; sugar is one commodity that keeps foreign competition at bay by relying on outdated quota system, raising sugar costs for consumers by about $1.9 billion a year; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: At the Ferrara Pan Candy Company, confectioners of everything from gummy bears to red hots, rail cars used to deliver three million pounds of sugar a week to its bustling plant just outside America's candy capital here. Today, the trains bring only half as much, barely enough to fill the factory's 65-foot sugar silos. That is largely because Ferrara, in an effort to avoid the high cost of government-protected American sugar, has been moving some of its century-old operations to Canada and Mexico.
docs.snippet: The sugar industry, which is being blamed for an assortment of evils, is losing some of its longtime political allies.

docs.lead_paragraph: Donaldson, Chairman of S.E.C., Announces That He Will Resign William H. Donaldson, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, announced his resignation, after repeated criticism from the two other Republican members of the agency and from some business groups and Bush administration officials who contended that his enforcement and policy decisions had been too aggressive. [Page A1.] Citigroup Said to Be in Talks to Sell Asset Management Unit Citigroup, which has been disposing of its noncore assets, is in talks with Legg Mason about a possible sale of its asset management unit, according to two executives who have been briefed on the discussions. [C1.] Questions on Timing of Guidant's Sales of Device Data provided by the Guidant Corporation to a Minnesota hospital suggests that the company continued to sell potentially flawed implantable heart defibrillators for months after it had changed the way it made the device and had begun selling new ones. [C1.] Mixed Signals From Economic Reports Manufacturing slowed, the prices of raw materials eased and housing thrived, according to new economic reports. [C1.] Stocks rose on economic news showing that inflation may be under control. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 82.39 points, to 10,549.87. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 10.72 points, at 1,202.22. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 19.64 points, or 1 percent, to 2,087.86. [C13.] Systems running the New York Stock Exchange abruptly shut down, halting all trading for about 12 minutes before the 4 p.m. close. [C3.] Crude Oil Prices Increase on Supply Concerns Crude oil prices rose 5 percent on revived concerns that supplies will be tight this summer and through the end of the year. Oil contracts for July delivery rose $2.61 to $54.58 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange on Wednesday, their highest since April 22. Oil prices, up 25 percent since the beginning of the year, have more than doubled in two years. [C13.] 'Big Sugar' Faces Criticism on Several Fronts The sugar industry, rightly or wrongly, is being blamed for an assortment of evils: undercutting the American food industries, fighting global diet guidelines to improve children's health and attack obesity, and for hurting the chance for passage of the Central American Free Trade Agreement. [C1.] Fannie Mae's Interim Chief Takes Job Permanently Fannie Mae, the nation's largest buyer of home loans, announced that Daniel H. Mudd, who since December has served as the company's interim chief executive, would keep the job permanently. [C3.] Arts Patron Left a Trail of Angry Investors Alberto Vilar, the arts patron and investment adviser who is charged with stealing $5 million from a client, is being accused by at three other people of taking millions of dollars more and refusing to give it back. [E1.] Eyes on Kremlin After Guilty Verdict in Oil Case The guilty verdict in the trial of the Russia oil billionaire Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky has led investors to wonder whether the case could be repeated. [C6.] Japanese Carmakers Continue to Surpass U.S. Rivals Even though General Motors and Ford continued to have difficulty selling cars at home, they did show some improvement last month. Toyota and Nissan, meanwhile, continued to post healthy sales gains. [C3.] Vaccine Shows Promise in Combating Shingles An experimental vaccine made by Merck can reduce both the incidence and the severity of shingles by more than half, doctors reported, in a development that could spare hundreds of thousands of elderly Americans from an extremely painful disease. [A1.] Merck is introducing what it describes as the first campaign in its 114-year history meant to help burnish the reputation of its corporate brand rather than sell products. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C7.] Airbus to Delay Delivery of Its A380 Jet Airbus, in the middle of an escalating trade battle with Boeing, has run into trouble on two other fronts, delaying the delivery of its flagship A380 superjumbo jet, left, and the expected announcement of a new chief executive. Airbus confirmed that it would push back delivery of the A380 to its first set of customers by as much as six months. The delay, which Airbus said was because of industrial and design modifications to the plane, could force it to pay steep penalties to those airlines. [C6.] Tidy Storage Options for Information Pack Rats Online data lockers -- when they work -- allow computer users to retrieve files from anywhere. Circuits. [C11.]
